abstract: Responding to a letter from Microsoft that threatened to lower the price of its buyout offer, Yahoo called Microsoft’s bid too low.
snippet: Responding to a letter from Microsoft that threatened to lower the price of its buyout offer, Yahoo called Microsoft’s bid too low.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo on Monday reiterated its rejection of a takeover offer from Microsoft, again calling it too low.

headline.print_headline: Yahoo Repeats Rejection of Microsoft Bid

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: Yahoo’s is expected to reject merger negotiations with Microsoft and explain why its board believes the current offer price is too low.
snippet: Yahoo’s is expected to reject merger negotiations with Microsoft and explain why its board believes the current offer price is too low.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo is expected to respond by early Monday to a letter from Microsoft that threatened to lower the price of its buyout offer and take it directly to Yahoo shareholders, people close to the company said on Sunday.

headline.main: Yahoo Is Said to Rebuff Microsoft Threat Over Bid
headline.print_headline: Yahoo Is Said to Rebuff Threat Over Bid

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: A startup called MokaFive, founded by four Stanford University computer scientists, is unveiling software that is designed to bring the advantages of so-called virtual machine software from server computers to the desktop.
snippet: A startup called MokaFive, founded by four Stanford University computer scientists, is unveiling software that is designed to bring the advantages of so-called virtual machine software from server computers to the desktop.
lead_paragraph: So-called virtual machine software, which allows a computer to simultaneously run different operating systems and applications, is already having a big impact in corporate data centers. And the leader in virtual software for server computers, VMware, has been a big winner, a hot I.P.O. last summer (current market capitalization: $19 billion), and important enough to attract the wrath of — and competitive salvos from — Microsoft.

headline.main: Aiming for a Virtual End to PC Headaches

abstract: Responding to Microsoft‘s threat to lower the price of its buyout offer over the weekend, Yahoo said Monday that it continues to believe that Microsoft’s takeover bid is too low, as do many of its shareholders. Yahoo also countered Microsoft’s assertions that its business has deteriorated since Microsoft made its unsolicited bid on January 31.
lead_paragraph: Responding to Microsoft‘s threat to lower the price of its buyout offer over the weekend, Yahoo said Monday that it continues to believe that Microsoft’s takeover bid is too low, as do many of its shareholders. Yahoo also countered Microsoft’s assertions that its business has deteriorated since Microsoft made its unsolicited bid on January 31.

headline.main: Yahoo Rebuffs Microsoft Threat Over Bid

abstract: Facebook is close to resolving a legal dispute about who really came up with the idea for the popular social-networking site, which sold a minority stake to Microsoft last October in a deal that valued the entire company at about $15 billion.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is close to resolving a legal dispute about who really came up with the idea for the popular social-networking site, which sold a minority stake to Microsoft last October in a deal that valued the entire company at about $15 billion.

headline.main: Facebook to Settle Lawsuit About Its Origins

abstract: In its latest letter to Microsoft, Yahoo doesn’t even try to argue it will be better off as an independent company. It simply demands more money.
snippet: In its latest letter to Microsoft, Yahoo doesn’t even try to argue it will be better off as an independent company. It simply demands more money.
lead_paragraph: Despite its defiant tones, Yahoo’s response to Microsoft Monday morning looks like the letter of a defeated company.

headline.main: Is Yahoo’s Letter the First Concession?

abstract: Microsoft is talking tough these days. Far from signaling it might raise its bid for Yahoo, it dangled the threat over the weekend that it could lower its offer and formally go hostile — and possibly both at the same time. For good measure, Steven Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, also set the clock ticking on a three-week deadline for Yahoo to agree to a deal.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is talking tough these days. Far from signaling it might raise its bid for Yahoo, it dangled the threat over the weekend that it could lower its offer and formally go hostile — and possibly both at the same time. For good measure, Steven Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, also set the clock ticking on a three-week deadline for Yahoo to agree to a deal.

headline.main: Yahoo’s Big Question: Is Steve Ballmer Bluffing?
